Award.AwardTitle: Catalytic methods for site-specific modification of natural proteins
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Zachary Ball from Rice University to investigate chemical reactions for protein modification. Proteins are incredibly large and complex molecules and selective alteration of proteins remains a daunting challenge. Nonetheless, chemically-modified proteins represent tantalizing opportunities. Applications of modified proteins include biomaterials for coatings or green energy and biological probes to understand, perturb, and inhibit biological pathways. Efforts under this award focus on developing new metal-mediated methods for protein modification. These novel methods allow the preparation of new sites with novel structures, reactivity, and biological properties. The research project is providing undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows with training in synthetic organic and inorganic chemistry. In addition, these research participants are receiving training in techniques and modern analytical methods of protein chemistry. An integrated outreach program is introducing modern protein chemistry and analytical methods to local high school teachers and their students.

In order to develop sequence-selective protein modification catalysts, this project employs rhodium(II) conjugates that enable modification of proteins, whether purified or in lysate, on the basis of molecular recognition. Catalytic modification provides a covalent readout for the presence and location of ligand binding, and thus allows identification of ligand-binding sites of "hit" compounds. The reactivity can also be harnessed to quantify inhibitors of weak, transient interactions that are difficult to study with existing methods. In a new direction, Chan-Lam coupling of boronate reagents allows copper-catalyzed modification of peptides and proteins, with unique sequence specificity. Unnatural chemical modification of metalloenzyme active sites has emerged as a powerful tool in metalloenzyme design. Boronate coupling promises to provide exciting new tools to build hybrid metalloproteins with new function and reactivity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project produced a set of techniques to modify natural proteins and peptides using simple boronic acid reagents. These techniques allow chemists to modify proteins at separate and specific sites of a very complex protein structure, with site reactivity controlled by the specific boronic acid reagent employed. These efforts developed complementary methods that selectively react at N-terminal, side-chain, or backbone amide sites. The amide backbone modification, in particular, provides a direct perturbation of backbone N-H bonds, with control protein folding, shape, and function. These efforts provide, in many cases, the only effective solution to perturb these important backbone structures. One important outgrowth of this study was the development of reagents that can be controlled by visible light, allowing a chemist to control protein or peptide function through external light. New synthetic strategies to build complex boronic acids aided both of these investigations, by permitting new access to reagents. In parallel, we investigated rhodium compounds that are used to induce reactions on proteins, and studied how structure and bond strength impacts the stability and utility of these useful rhodium complexes. These studies provide new insight into metal-based methods to selectively control the function of an individual protein within a large family of highly similar structures, by avoiding the cross-interactions common with traditional approaches.

This project produced broader impacts in the form of building a pipeline to higher education for at-risk high school students from local schools with large populations of historically underrepresented groups. A robust teacher-training program built bridges with local high school, in the form of increasing awareness of research careers, and the development of specific new curricular programs to incorporate exciting modern research challenges into the high school chemistry curriculum. The research conducted under the project allowed several undergraduate students to launch successful research careers through authorship on peer-reviewed publications and matriculation into Ph.D. programs in chemistry.
